elements.content: Solvothermal reactions of bulk CuSCN with six flexible benzimidazolyl-based ligands with different spacer lengths [(bzim)(CH2) n (bzim)] (bzim = benzimidazolyl; n = 1, mbbm; n = 2, ebbm; n = 3, prbbm; n = 4, bbbm; n = 5, pbbm; n = 6, hbbm) afforded a series of new [CuSCN] n -supported coordination polymers, [(CuSCN)2(mbbm)] n (1), [(CuSCN)2(ebbm)2] n (2), [(Cu(SCN)2(prbbm)] n (3a), [{(CuSCN)2(prbbm)2}·2MeCN] n (3b), [(CuSCN)4(bbbm)3] n (4), [(CuSCN)2(pbbm)] n (5), and [(CuSCN)2(hbbm)] n (6), respectively. Compounds 1−6 were characterized by elemental analysis, IR, and X-ray crystallography. Compound 1, 3a, or 6 possesses the similar staircase-like [CuSCN] n chains that are bridged by mbbm, prbbm, or hbbm to form one one-dimensional (1D) chain with an oblong channel (3a) or two two-dimensional (2D) networks (1 and 6). Compound 2 or 3b consists of a dimeric [CuSCN]2 fragment that serves either as a 4-connecting node to link the other four equivalent ones via two pairs of ebbm bridges to form a 2D (4,4) network (2) or as a 2-connecting node to bridge its two adjacent ones via a pair of prbbm bridges to form a 1D chain (3b). Compound 4 contains a new kind of [CuSCN] n double chain that is connected by bbbm with two conformations to form a unique 2D network, while 5 consists of a [CuSCN] n single chain that is linked by pbbm to form the other kind of 1D chain with an oblong channel. In addition, the photoluminescent properties of 1−6 in solid state at ambient temperature were also investigated.

elements.content: The construction of inorganic−organic hybrid coordination polymers has been of great interest in recent years, due to not only their intriguing architectures and topologies but also their potential applications in optoelectronic, catalytic, and magnetic materials. Coordination polymers are usually produced from simple self-assembly reactions of metal ions with multitopic ligands. Those derived from the reactions of group 11 metal halides (Cl, Br, I) or pseudohalides (CN, SCN) with bidentate nitrogen ligands are particularly interesting because of their structural diversities and their luminescent properties. Among the halides and pseudohalides, thiocyanate, as an ambidentate ligand, holds versatile binding modes through its nitrogen and sulfur ends. Recent studies have shown that the three-dimensional (3D) framework of bulk CuSCN could be cracked by various multitopic N-heterocyclic ligands in organic solvents to produce [CuSCN] n -based structural motifs. Apart from the α and β forms of the 3D framework of copper(I) thiocyanate itself, staircase-like [CuSCN] n layers and one-dimensional (1D) [CuSCN] n single and double chains were also observed. The factors that may influence the outcomes of such a cracking reaction include the CuSCN-to-ligand ratio, the reaction temperatures, and the solvent systems. Several reports demonstrated that the spacer length of the bridging ligand may also make a remarkable impact on the topological structures of the cracked products. For example, the reactions of CuSCN with three bidentate linkers with different spacer lengths, 4,4′-bipyridine (4,4′-bipy), 1,2-(4-pyridyl)ethene (bpe), and 1,3-(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp) gave rise to a 3D polymer [(CuSCN)2(4,4′-bipy)] n , a two-dimensional (2D) polymer [(CuSCN)2(bpe)] n , and a single-walled coordination nanotube [{CuSCN(bpp)}·(DMF)0.5] n , respectively. However, it is noted that the aforementioned examples were randomly reported, and few have been devoted to the study of how a family of the bridging ligands with different spacer lengths influences the frameworks of the final [CuSCN] n -based coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The construction of inorganic-organic hybrid coordination polymers has been of great interest in recent years, due to not only their intriguing architectures and topologies but also their potential applications in optoelectronic, catalytic, and magnetic materials. Coordination polymers are usually produced from simple self-assembly reactions of metal ions with multitopic ligands. Those derived from the reactions of group 11 metal halides (Cl, Br, I) or pseudohalides (CN, SCN) with bidentate nitrogen ligands are particularly interesting because of their structural diversities and their luminescent properties. Among the halides and pseudohalides, thiocyanate, as an ambidentate ligand, holds versatile binding modes through its nitrogen and sulfur ends. Recent studies have shown that the three-dimensional (3D) framework of bulk CuSCN could be cracked by various multitopic N-heterocyclic ligands in organic solvents to produce [CuSCN] n -based structural motifs. Apart from the α and β forms of the 3D framework of copper(I) thiocyanate itself, staircase-like [CuSCN] n  layers and one-dimensional (1D) [CuSCN] n  single and double chains were also observed. The factors that may influence the outcomes of such a cracking reaction include the CuSCN-to-ligand ratio, the reaction temperatures, and the solvent systems. Several reports demonstrated that the spacer length of the bridging ligand may also make a remarkable impact on the topological structures of the cracked products. For example, the reactions of CuSCN with three bidentate linkers with different spacer lengths, 4,4'-bipyridine (4,4'-bipy), 1,2-(4-pyridyl)ethene (bpe), and 1,3-(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp) gave rise to a 3D polymer [(CuSCN)2(4,4'-bipy)] n , a two-dimensional (2D) polymer [(CuSCN)2(bpe)] n , and a single-walled coordination nanotube [{CuSCN(bpp)}⋅(DMF)0.5] n , respectively. However, it is noted that the aforementioned examples were randomly reported, and few have been devoted to the study of how a family of the bridging ligands with different spacer lengths influences the frameworks of the final [CuSCN] n -based coordination polymers.

elements.content: In our previous reports, we have demonstrated a synthetic approach to [Cu n I n ]-based coordination polymers through cracking the 3D framework of bulk CuI using multitopic N-heterocyclic ligands at solvothermal conditions. We found that the 3D skeleton of the bulk CuI was cleaved into various [Cu n I n ] motifs, which were further connected by these ligands to form 1D or 2D polymers. What about the reactions of bulk CuSCN with the multitopic N-heterocyclic ligands at solvothermal conditions? We deliberately chose a set of the flexible benzimidazolyl-based linkers with different spacer lengths, [(bzim)(CH2) n (bzim)] (bzim = benzimidazolyl; n = 1, mbbm; n = 2, ebbm; n = 3, prbbm; n = 4, bbbm; n = 5, pbbm; n = 6, hbbm) (Scheme ), most of which have not been employed for the construction of coordination polymers so far. Their solvothermal cracking reactions with bulk CuSCN did produce the different [CuSCN] n motifs (Scheme ) and the different [CuSCN] n -based 1D or 2D coordination polymers, [(CuSCN)2(mbbm)] n (1), [(CuSCN)2(ebbm)2] n (2), [(Cu(SCN)2(prbbm)] n (3a), [{(CuSCN)2(prbbm)2}·2MeCN] n (3b), [(CuSCN)4(bbbm)3] n (4), [(CuSCN)2(pbbm)] n (5), and [(CuSCN)2(hbbm)] n (6). In this article, we report their reactions, crystal structures, and solid state photoluminescent properties.

elements.content: All of the ligands were prepared according to the literature methods. Other chemicals and reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used as received. Acetonitrile was predried with activated molecular sieves and refluxed over the appropriate drying agents under argon. The IR spectra (KBr disk) were recorded on a Varian Scimitar-1000 spectrometer (400−4000 cm−1). The elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed with an EA1110 CHNS elemental analyzer. The emission and excitation spectra were measured on a Varian Cary Elipse fluorescence spectrophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
Materials and Methods

All of the ligands were prepared according to the literature methods. Other chemicals and reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used as received. Acetonitrile was predried with activated molecular sieves and refluxed over the appropriate drying agents under argon. The IR spectra (KBr disk) were recorded on a Varian Scimitar-1000 spectrometer (400-4000 cm-1). The elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed with an EA1110 CHNS elemental analyzer. The emission and excitation spectra were measured on a Varian Cary Elipse fluorescence spectrophotometer.

elements.content: A mixture of CuSCN (12 mg, 0.1 mmol), mbbm (12 mg, 0.05 mmol), and MeCN (2 mL) was loaded into a Pyrex glass tube. It was then sealed and heated to 140 °C for two days, and cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h. Colorless blocks of 1 were formed, which were collected by filtration, washed with MeCN/Et2O (v/v = 1:4) and dried in air. Yield: 35% (based on Cu). Anal. Calcd for C17H12Cu2N6S2: C, 41.54; H, 2.46; N, 17.10%. Found: C, 41.58; H, 2.29; N, 17.15%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3099 (w), 2991 (w), 2902 (w), 2115 (s), 2062 (s), 1504 (s), 1390 (m), 1358 (m), 1289 (m), 1246 (s), 1205 (m), 1000 (m), 758 (s), 592 (w), 424 (m).

elements.content: Crystals of 1−6 suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained directly from the above preparations. All of the measurements were performed on a Rigaku Mercury CCD X-ray diffractometer by using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å). Single crystals of 1−6 were mounted at the top of a glass fiber with grease. Compounds 1, 2, 3a, 3b, 4, and 6 were cooled to 223 K in a liquid-nitrogen stream, while 5 was kept at 293 K. Cell parameters were refined by using the program CrystalClear (Rigaku and MSC, version 1.3, 2001). The collected data were reduced by using the program Crystalstructure (Rigaku and MSC, version 3.60, 2004) while an absorption correction (multiscan) was applied. The reflection data were also corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallographic Study

Crystals of 1-6 suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained directly from the above preparations. All of the measurements were performed on a Rigaku Mercury CCD X-ray diffractometer by using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å). Single crystals of 1-6 were mounted at the top of a glass fiber with grease. Compounds 1, 2, 3a, 3b, 4, and 6 were cooled to 223 K in a liquid-nitrogen stream, while 5 was kept at 293 K. Cell parameters were refined by using the program CrystalClear (Rigaku and MSC, version 1.3, 2001). The collected data were reduced by using the program Crystalstructure (Rigaku and MSC, version 3.60, 2004) while an absorption correction (multiscan) was applied. The reflection data were also corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects.

elements.content: The crystal structures of 1−6 were solved by the direct method and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares techniques with the SHELXTL-97 program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and all hydrogen atoms were placed in geometrically idealized positions (C−H = 0.98 Å (1, 2, 3a, 3b, 4, and 6), or 0.97 Å (5), with U iso(H) = 1.2U eq(C) for methylene groups; C−H = 0.94 Å (1, 2, 3a, 3b, 4, and 6), or 0.93 Å (5), with U iso(H) = 1.2U eq(C) for aromatic rings) and constrained to ride on their parent atoms. A summary of the key crystallographic information for 1−6 is tabulated in Table , and their selected bond lengths and angles are given in Table .

Solvothermal treatment of bulk CuSCN with L (L = mbbm, prbbm, pbbm, hbbm) in 2:1 molar ratio at 140 °C (1, 3a, and 6) for two days or 160 °C (5) for two days produced 1 (35% yield), 3a (28% yield), 5 (40% yield), and 6 (30% yield), respectively. Analogous cracking reactions of CuSCN with equimolar L (L = ebbm, prbbm, or bbbm) at 180 °C for two days (2, 3b) or 140 °C (4) for three days afforded 2 (42% yield), 3b (30% yield), and 4 (36% yield), respectively. As shown in Scheme , during these reactions, the 3D framework of bulk CuSCN was cracked by these ligands into several [CuSCN] n -based species, including one 1D staircase-like [CuSCN] n chain (motif a) and one 1D [CuSCN] n double chain (motif b), one [CuSCN] n single chain (motif c), and one dimeric [CuSCN]2 fragment (motif d). In all of the cases, if the reaction temperature was fixed, changes of CuSCN/L molar ratios from 1:1 to 1:2 to 2:1 always generated the same product in varied yields. Increasing the temperature from 140 to 180 °C did not form different products but raised the yield of the final product, which was the case for the formation of 2 and 5. However, in the case of prbbm, varying the different reaction temperatures afforded two different products 3a and 3b. As described later in this article, the former contains a 1D staircase-like [CuSCN] n chain while the latter only a dimeric [CuSCN]2 fragment. It is understandable that when the temperature was increased, the 3D framework of bulk CuSCN would be cleaved to form a staircase-like [CuSCN] n chain observed in 3a, which might be further cracked into a dimeric [CuSCN]2 fragment in 3b. Finally, the above six bridging ligands with different spacer lengths adopted different ways to pick up the resulting [CuSCN] n motifs to form different topological structures. Even though the resulting [CuSCN] n motifs are the same, they are connected by linkers with different spacer lengths to form different frameworks. For example, the dimeric [CuSCN]2 fragments were bridged by ebbm or prbbm to afford a 2D polymer (2) and a 1D polymer (3b). Linking the 1D staircase-like [CuSCN] n chains with mbbm, prbbm, or hbbm gave rise to a 2D layer polymer (1), a 1D polymer with an oblong channel (3a), and a 2D wave-like polymer (6), respectively.

Results and Discussion

Synthetic and Spectral Aspects

Solvothermal treatment of bulk CuSCN with L (L = mbbm, prbbm, pbbm, hbbm) in 2:1 molar ratio at 140 °C (1, 3a, and 6) for two days or 160 °C (5) for two days produced 1 (35% yield), 3a (28% yield), 5 (40% yield), and 6 (30% yield), respectively. Analogous cracking reactions of CuSCN with equimolar L (L = ebbm, prbbm, or bbbm) at 180 °C for two days (2, 3b) or 140 °C (4) for three days afforded 2 (42% yield), 3b (30% yield), and 4 (36% yield), respectively. As shown in Scheme , during these reactions, the 3D framework of bulk CuSCN was cracked by these ligands into several [CuSCN] n -based species, including one 1D staircase-like [CuSCN] n  chain (motif a) and one 1D [CuSCN] n  double chain (motif b), one [CuSCN] n  single chain (motif c), and one dimeric [CuSCN]2 fragment (motif d). In all of the cases, if the reaction temperature was fixed, changes of CuSCN/L molar ratios from 1:1 to 1:2 to 2:1 always generated the same product in varied yields. Increasing the temperature from 140 to 180 °C did not form different products but raised the yield of the final product, which was the case for the formation of 2 and 5. However, in the case of prbbm, varying the different reaction temperatures afforded two different products 3a and 3b. As described later in this article, the former contains a 1D staircase-like [CuSCN] n  chain while the latter only a dimeric [CuSCN]2 fragment. It is understandable that when the temperature was increased, the 3D framework of bulk CuSCN would be cleaved to form a staircase-like [CuSCN] n  chain observed in 3a, which might be further cracked into a dimeric [CuSCN]2 fragment in 3b. Finally, the above six bridging ligands with different spacer lengths adopted different ways to pick up the resulting [CuSCN] n  motifs to form different topological structures. Even though the resulting [CuSCN] n  motifs are the same, they are connected by linkers with different spacer lengths to form different frameworks. For example, the dimeric [CuSCN]2 fragments were bridged by ebbm or prbbm to afford a 2D polymer (2) and a 1D polymer (3b). Linking the 1D staircase-like [CuSCN] n  chains with mbbm, prbbm, or hbbm gave rise to a 2D layer polymer (1), a 1D polymer with an oblong channel (3a), and a 2D wave-like polymer (6), respectively.

elements.content: Compounds 1−6 are relatively air- and moisture-stable, and insoluble in common organic solvents such as CH2Cl2, MeCN, DMF, and DMSO. The elemental analysis was consistent with the chemical formulas of 1−6. In the IR spectra of 1−6, the strong bands at 2115/2062 (1), 2097 (2), 2129/2099 (3a), 2121 (3b), 2106 (4), 2175/2101 (5), and 2105 (6) cm−1 were assigned to be the CN stretching vibrations of the bridging thiocyanate ligands. Bands at 1504 (1), 1504 (2), 1508 (3a), 1502 (3b), 1511(4), 1507 (5), and 1507 (6) cm−1 were assigned as the CN stretching vibrations of benzimidazolyl groups. The identities of 1−6 were further confirmed by X-ray crystallography.

elements.content: Compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c, and the asymmetric unit consists of half a neutral [Cu2(SCN)2(mbbm)] molecule. Compound 1 possesses a 2D layer structure (extending along the bc plane) constructed by linking the 1D staircase-like [CuSCN] n chains via mbbm bridges (Figure a). Each [CuSCN] n chain (extending along the b axis) is assembled from linking each eight-membered Cu−NCS−Cu−NCS ring via four Cu−S(SCN) bonds. Such a chain was observed in [(CuSCN)2(bpe)] n and [Cu(SCN)(dpt)] n (dpt = 2,4-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine). In each chain, each thiocyanate is almost linear with the S−C−N bond angle 178.8(7)°, which is comparable to those of the corresponding ones of [Cu(SCN)(py)] n (178.1(5)°). Each Cu(I) center in 1 is tetrahedrally coordinated by one N atom from one mbbm ligand, one N from one thiocyanate, and two S atoms from another two thiocyanates (Figure b). The Cu−S bond lengths ranging from 2.411(2) Å to 2.868(3) Å are much longer than those found in [Cu2(SCN)2(4,4′-bipy)] n (2.3549(13) Å) and [{CuSCN(bpp)}·(DMF)0.5] n (2.331(1) Å), but Cu1−S1 is shorter than that of [Cu2(SCN)2(bpe)] n (2.4203(8) and 2.5172(8) Å, bpe = 1,2-trans-(4-pyridyl)ethene). The Cu−N(mbbm) bond length (1.963(5) Å) is significantly longer than that of Cu−N(SCN) (1.896(5) Å), but they are all shorter than the corresponding ones in the aforementioned complexes. For each mbbm ligand, the two benzimidazolyl groups are oriented at different directions with the N−to−N distance of 2.3804 Å (N2/N2B pair) and the dihedral angle of 66.7°.

elements.content: Compound 2 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅, and the asymmetric unit consists of half a [(CuSCN)2(ebbm)2] molecule. As shown in Figure a, there is a crystallographic center of symmetry lying at the center of Cu1 and Cu1A contact in the dimeric [(CuSCN)2(ebbm)2] molecule. Each Cu atom is tetrahedrally coordinated by one S atom of one SCN ligand, one N atom of the other SCN ligand, and two N atoms from two different ebbm ligands. The mean Cu−S, Cu−N(NCS), and Cu−N(ebbm) bond lengths are longer than those of the corresponding ones in 1. The two benzimidazolyl groups in each ebbm ligand are parallel but direct at different orientations. Each ebbm ligand takes a trans−trans configuration with the N−to−N distance of 3.731 Å (N2/N2B pair) or 3.732 Å (N4/N4C pair). From the topological view, each [CuSCN]2 fragment in 2 works as an uncommon planar four-connecting node to interlink the other four equivalent ones via two pairs of ebbm ligands to form a 2D (4,4) network extending along the ab plane (Figure b).

elements.content: Compound 3a crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n, and the asymmetric unit consists of one [(CuSCN)2(prbbm)] molecule. In the [(CuSCN)2(prbbm)] molecule, each Cu(I) adopts a tetrahedral coordination geometry, coordinated by two S atoms of two different SCN, one N atom from SCN and one N atom from one prbbm ligand (Figure a). The longer Cu−S (av. 2.721(3) Å) and the shorter Cu−S (av. 2.293(2) Å) bond lengths are shorter than those of the corresponding ones in 1. The mean Cu−N(prbbm) and Cu−N(SCN) bond lengths (1.987(6) Å vs 1.953(6) Å) are longer than those of the corresponding ones in 1. Each prbbm ligand has a gauche−gauche configuration with a N−to−N distance of 4.376 Å (N2/N3 pair) and a dihedral angle of 24.4° between the benzimidazolyl groups. In the structure of 3a, two staircase-like [CuSCN] n chains, which are almost the same as those in 1, are arranged to be parallel and staggered. Pairs of prbbm ligands wind around two chains, thereby forming a 1D chain with an oblong channel (cross section area = 3.86 Å × 13.27 Å) extending along the a axis (Figure b and c).

In the structure of 3a, two staircase-like [CuSCN] n  chains, which are almost the same as those in 1, are arranged to be parallel and staggered. elements.content: Compound 3b crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ and the asymmetric unit consists of half a [(CuSCN)2(prbbm)2] molecule and one MeCN solvent molecule. As shown in Figure d, each Cu atom in the centrosymmetric [(CuSCN)2(prbbm)2] molecule is tetrahedrally coordinated by one S atom of one SCN ligand, one N atom of the other SCN ligand, and two N atoms from different prbbm ligands. The mean Cu−S and Cu−N(prbbm) bond lengths are slightly shorter than those of the corresponding ones in 2, while the mean Cu1−N(SCN) bond length is longer than that in 2. Like 3a, each prbbm ligand takes a gauche−gauche configuration with the N−to−N distance of 4.387 Å (N2/N3 pair) and a dihedral angle of 106.9° between the benzimidazolyl groups. Topologically, the dimeric [CuSCN]2 fragments are linked by couples of prbbm bridges to form a 1D chain extending along the c axis (Figure e). Alternatively, the 1D chain may be viewed as having 18-membered [Cu(prbbm)]2 metallomacrocycles that are bridged by pairs of thiocyanates.

elements.content: Compound 4 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅, and the asymmetric unit has one-half of the [(CuSCN)4(bbbm)3] molecule. As shown in Figure a, the tetrameric [(CuSCN)4(bbbm)3] molecule is centrosymmetric, and each Cu(I) atom adopts a distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry, coordinated by one S atom and one N atom from two SCN ligands and two N atoms from two bbbm ligands (Cu1), or by one N atom and two S atoms from three SCN ligands and one N atom from one bbbm ligand (Cu2). The Cu2−S2 bond length is shorter than Cu1−S1, and their mean value (2.3145(19) Å) is in-between those of the corresponding ones in 1 and 3a. The average Cu−N(bbbm) and Cu−N(NCS) bond lengths (2.032(5) Å vs 1.967(5) Å) are slightly longer than those of the corresponding ones of 1 and 3a. It is noted that the bbbm ligands in 4 show two kinds of configurations. One has a gauche−gauche configuration with the N−to−N distance of 5.792 Å (N2/N3 pair) and the dihedral angle of 80.5° between the benzimidazolyl groups, while the other has a trans−trans configuration with the benzimidazolyl groups being parallel to each other and the N−to−N distance of 5.348 Å (N6/N6D pair).

elements.content: Topologically, the [CuSCN] n double chain in 4 is evidently different from those in 1 and 3a, and has never been reported previously. It contains a chairlike 12-membered Cu−NCS−Cu−S−Cu−NCS−Cu−S ring that shares four SCN ligands with its two neighboring ones. In this double chain, Cu1 in one chain connects with its symmetry-related one in the other via one bbbm ligand (pink line highlighted in Figure b), while Cu2 in one chain and its symmetry-related one in the other are linked by the other kind of bbbm ligand (green line highlighted in Figure b). The two kinds of bbbm ligands are interlaced with the [CuSCN] n double chains, thereby forming an extremely rare self-penetrated 2D network with an uncommon (2·4·5·62·7)(4·5·63·8) Schläfli symbol.

elements.content: Compound 5 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅, and the asymmetric unit consists of one [(CuSCN)2(pbbm)] molecule. Each Cu(I) atom shows a trigonal planar coordination geometry, coordinated by one S atom and one N atom from two SCN ligands, and one N atom from one pbbm ligand (Figure a). The Cu1−N1 (1.959(3) Å) bond length is shorter, but the Cu1−N5 (1.921(4) Å) and Cu1−S2 (2.2611(14) Å) bond lengths are longer than the corresponding ones in [Cu(SCN)L] (L = 2,6-dimethylpyridine). Each pbbm ligand exhibits a gauche−gauche configuration with the N−to−N distance of 6.460 Å (N2/N3 pair) and the dihedral angle of 14.6° between the benzimidazolyl groups. In 5, there are two single 1D zigzag [CuSCN] n chains, which were also observed in [CuSCN(μ-2-Mepyz)] n (2-Mepyz = 2-Methylpyrazine) and [CuSCN(bpa)] n [bpa = 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane]. The two chains are parallel to each other and are arranged in a face-to-face way, which affords the weak Cu−S interaction (2.938 Å) between Cu in one chain and S(SCN) in the other (2.938 Å), and the weak Cu···Cu interaction (3.051 Å). Each pbbm ligand winds the two chains using its one N end to bind at one Cu of one chain and the other N end to link one Cu of the other chain, thereby forming a 1D chain with the other kind of 1D chain with an oblong channel extending along the c axis (Figure b and c). The cross-section area for such a channel is ca. 2.94 Å × 11.19 Å, where no solvent molecules are found.

elements.content: Compound 6 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c, and the asymmetric unit consists of half a [(CuSCN)2(hbbm)] molecule. In the centrosymmetric [(CuSCN)2(hbbm)] molecule, each Cu is tetrahedrally coordinated by one N and two S atoms from three SCN ligands and one N atom from one hbbm ligand (Figure a). Within the dimeric Cu2S2 rhomb, the two kinds of Cu−S bond lengths are somewhat shorter than those of the corresponding ones in 1 and 3a, while the Cu−N(SCN) and Cu−N(hbbm) bond lengths are comparable to those of the corresponding ones in 1 and 3a. Each hbbm ligand has a trans−trans configuration with the N−to−N distance of 8.779 (N2/N2C pair) and the benzimidazole groups being parallel to each other. The 1D staircase-like [CuSCN] n chain (extending long the a axis) in 6 is almost the same as those in 1 and 3a. Each chain interconnects with its neighboring ones via long hbbm bridges to form a 2D wave-like network extending along the ab plane (Figure b).

elements.content: The photoluminescent properties of 1−6 in solid state at room temperature were studied (Figure ). For 1, excitation at 360 nm produced an intense blue−green emission with a peak maximum at 490 nm, which is red-shifted relative to that of mbbm (λex max = 270 nm; λem max = 303 nm). This emission may be associated with a ligand-centered excited state with a possible involvement of metal-to-ligand or ligand-to-ligand charge transfer. For 2 and 3b, upon excitation at 350 nm, they exhibited strong photoluminescence with emission maxima at 497 and 465 nm, respectively. A red shift occurred compared to those of ebbm (λex max = 270 nm; λem max = 310 nm) and prbbm (λex max = 250 nm; λem max = 332 nm). These emissions may be due to the cluster-centered (CC*) transition. For 3a and 4−6, upon excitation at 370 nm (3a), 330 nm (4), 350 nm (5), and 330 nm (6), 3a and 4−6 produced intense emission maxima at 434 nm (3a), 485 nm (4), 475 nm (5), or 510 nm (6). A red shift was also observed compared to those of prbbm (λex max = 250 nm; λem max = 332 nm), bbbm (λex max = 295 nm; λem max = 445 nm), pbbm (λex max = 280 nm; λem max = 345 nm), and hbbm (λex max = 280 nm; λem max = 355 nm). The emission origins of 3a and 4−6 might be assigned to be the metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) with electrons being transferred from Cu(I) centers to the unoccupied π* orbitals of the thiocyanide groups. The emission maxima of 3a and 4−6 are comparable to those of other copper(I)−thiocyanide complexes such as [{CuSCN(bpp)}·(DMF)0.5] n (480 nm) and [Cu2(SCN)2(dps)] n (538 nm, dps = 4,4′-dipyridyl sulfide).

Photoluminescent Properties

The photoluminescent properties of 1-6 in solid state at room temperature were studied (Figure ). For 1, excitation at 360 nm produced an intense blue-green emission with a peak maximum at 490 nm, which is red-shifted relative to that of mbbm (λex max = 270 nm; λem max = 303 nm). This emission may be associated with a ligand-centered excited state with a possible involvement of metal-to-ligand or ligand-to-ligand charge transfer. For 2 and 3b, upon excitation at 350 nm, they exhibited strong photoluminescence with emission maxima at 497 and 465 nm, respectively. A red shift occurred compared to those of ebbm (λex max = 270 nm; λem max = 310 nm) and prbbm (λex max = 250 nm; λem max = 332 nm). These emissions may be due to the cluster-centered (CC*) transition. For 3a and 4-6, upon excitation at 370 nm (3a), 330 nm (4), 350 nm (5), and 330 nm (6), 3a and 4-6 produced intense emission maxima at 434 nm (3a), 485 nm (4), 475 nm (5), or 510 nm (6). A red shift was also observed compared to those of prbbm (λex max = 250 nm; λem max = 332 nm), bbbm (λex max = 295 nm; λem max = 445 nm), pbbm (λex max = 280 nm; λem max = 345 nm), and hbbm (λex max = 280 nm; λem max = 355 nm). The emission origins of 3a and 4-6 might be assigned to be the metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) with electrons being transferred from Cu(I) centers to the unoccupied π* orbitals of the thiocyanide groups. The emission maxima of 3a and 4-6 are comparable to those of other copper(I)-thiocyanide complexes such as [{CuSCN(bpp)}⋅(DMF)0.5] n  (480 nm) and [Cu2(SCN)2(dps)] n  (538 nm, dps = 4,4'-dipyridyl sulfide).

elements.content: In the work reported here, we have demonstrated an interesting approach to [CuSCN] n -based coordination polymers through cracking the 3D framework of bulk CuSCN using multitopic flexible N-heterocyclic ligands under solvothermal conditions. Seven 1D or 2D [CuSCN] n -based coordination polymers 1−6 were obtained from assembly of the resulting four [CuSCN] n motifs and a set of the six flexible benzimidazolyl-based linkers with different spacer lengths, [(bzim)(CH2) n (bzim)] (n = 1−6). It is noted that structural diversities of these frameworks may be greatly affected mainly by the flexible ligands with different spacer lengths. For instance, although 2 and 3b consist of the same dimeric [CuSCN]2 fragment, such a fragment can work as a 4-connecting node (2) or a 2-connecting node (3b) to link other equivalent ones to form a 2D polymer (2) or a 1D chain (3b). 1, 3a, and 6 contain the 1D staircase-like [CuSCN] n chains, which are linked by mbbm, prbbm, or hbbm to afford a 2D layer polymer (1), a 1D polymer with an oblong channel (3a), and a 2D wave-like polymer (6), respectively. It seems that the reaction temperature did not work in all cases; however, two completely different products 3a and 3b were produced by solvothermal reactions of CuSCN with prbbm at 140 or 180 °C. In addition, some structures reported in this article deserve comment. Compound 3a or 5 has one unique 1D chain with oblong channels assembled from prbbm bridges linking 1D staircase-like [CuSCN] n chains (3a) or pbbm bridges linking [CuSCN] n single chains (5). Compound 4 consists of a unique 2D network in which bbbm ligands with two different conformations connect with rare [CuSCN] n double chains. These results provided some insights into the cracking reactions of bulk CuSCN with the benzimidazolyl-based ligands and the related factors that may exert an impact on the formation of such [CuSCN] n -based coordination polymers. Further studies in this respect are underway in this laboratory.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In the work reported here, we have demonstrated an interesting approach to [CuSCN] n -based coordination polymers through cracking the 3D framework of bulk CuSCN using multitopic flexible N-heterocyclic ligands under solvothermal conditions. Seven 1D or 2D [CuSCN] n -based coordination polymers 1-6 were obtained from assembly of the resulting four [CuSCN] n  motifs and a set of the six flexible benzimidazolyl-based linkers with different spacer lengths, [(bzim)(CH2) n (bzim)] (n = 1-6). It is noted that structural diversities of these frameworks may be greatly affected mainly by the flexible ligands with different spacer lengths. For instance, although 2 and 3b consist of the same dimeric [CuSCN]2 fragment, such a fragment can work as a 4-connecting node (2) or a 2-connecting node (3b) to link other equivalent ones to form a 2D polymer (2) or a 1D chain (3b). 1, 3a, and 6 contain the 1D staircase-like [CuSCN] n  chains, which are linked by mbbm, prbbm, or hbbm to afford a 2D layer polymer (1), a 1D polymer with an oblong channel (3a), and a 2D wave-like polymer (6), respectively. It seems that the reaction temperature did not work in all cases; however, two completely different products 3a and 3b were produced by solvothermal reactions of CuSCN with prbbm at 140 or 180 °C. In addition, some structures reported in this article deserve comment. Compound 3a or 5 has one unique 1D chain with oblong channels assembled from prbbm bridges linking 1D staircase-like [CuSCN] n  chains (3a) or pbbm bridges linking [CuSCN] n  single chains (5). Compound 4 consists of a unique 2D network in which bbbm ligands with two different conformations connect with rare [CuSCN] n  double chains. These results provided some insights into the cracking reactions of bulk CuSCN with the benzimidazolyl-based ligands and the related factors that may exert an impact on the formation of such [CuSCN] n -based coordination polymers. Further studies in this respect are underway in this laboratory.
